awd_titl_txt: Energy Efficient Millimeter Wave Massive MIMO Wireless Communications
awd_abstract_narration:
Low-Power High-Performance Wireless Devices for Massive Connectivity
A. Lee Swindlehurst and  Michael Green  University of California Irvine


The so-called "Internet of Things'' (IoT) refers to the inter-networking of all types of physical devices in order to allow them to collect data and communicate with one another, or with an access point that allows them to exchange data with the internet and hence the entire world. There is a plethora of applications where such devices could be useful, including medicine, transportation, civil infrastructure, environmental monitoring, as well as personal communications. The ability of these devices to sense their environment and communicate with each other and the internet will lead to a revolution that will improve our health, our environment and our overall quality of life. In order for the IoT revolution to become a reality, significant advances are needed to reduce the cost of these devices (so that they can be deployed ubiquitously) as well as their energy consumption (so that they can operate for long periods of time without replacement). Advances in digital hardware over the past decades has resulted in circuit miniaturization that has in turn allowed for complicated microprocessors with billions of transistors to occupy a space no bigger than the head of a pin. Advances in nanofabrication have allowed for the creation of tiny sensors and actuators that require only very small amounts of energy or minimal access to their environment in order to operate. However, the physical constraints associated with analog electronic conversion, amplification and communication have been slower to be overcome. The goal of this project is to help remedy this gap, and develop simple, low-power, low-complexity radio-frequency devices that can be used in conjunction with sophisticated software to enable the IoT vision to become a reality. 

New techniques and hardware implementations are needed that reduce the size, cost and power consumption of transceivers that will enable ubiquitous deployment of IoT devices as well as energy efficient gigabit-per-second wireless networks. Motivated by this vision, our project focuses on several new research initiatives that will push wireless systems in this direction: (1) A new concept for massive MIMO RF hardware based on reconfigurable one-bit direct detection (DDA) antennas that potentially require neither mixers nor local oscillator generation and distribution, and enable simpler antenna feeding, high energy efficiency, lower cost and ultrafast signaling; (2) New integrated circuit implementations based on inductor tuning to validate the DDA concept and illustrate how mixer-less demodulation via wireless LO distribution can be used to dramatically simplify the RF front end for millimeter-wave frequency bands; (3) Uplink/downlink channel capacity results with one-bit ADCs/DACs that do not rely on the assumption of white quantization noise, based on a new derivation in the angular frequency domain. These results will be better suited for millimeter-wave channels that tend to be sparse and frequency-selective. (4) New types of finite field downlink precoders with one-bit DACs that do not require the standard arithmetic operations of multiplication and addition (and hence considerably simplify the necessary digital computations), and yet still substantially outperform conventional methods and can be combined with channel coding techniques; (5) More realistic models for low-resolution ADC and DAC hardware that account for out-of-band emissions and intermodulation products in the data, in order to determine under what conditions they can be ignored and how they can be mitigated otherwise. The anticipated research addresses critical challenges for next-generation wireless systems and is also of high relevance for the success of low-power IoT technology.

por.por_cntn:
Our world is becoming more and more dependent on access to data through high-speed wireless connections, with applications extending beyond traditional cellular telephony and military communications to include manufacturing, tele-medicine, autonomous vehicles, tele-presence, and other smart connected devices. To meet this exponentially increasing demand, engineers have begun to investigate novel radio frequency (RF) architectures, one of which is the use of arrays composed of large numbers of antennas (potentially in the 100?s). This leads to what is known as ?massive multi-input multi-output (MIMO)? communication systems, which can allow a multitude of simultaneous communication streams to co-exist at the same time and in the same frequency band, thus providing an increase in data throughput of an order of magnitude or more. The drawback to practical implementation of such systems is a corresponding order of magnitude or greater increase in cost, complexity, and power consumption.

In this project, our team has developed MIMO architectures that can be implemented with significantly reduced cost and much greater energy efficiency, simplifying the hardware and relying more on sophisticated signal processing to counteract the inevitable non-idealities that result from the simpler hardware. In particular, we have focused on receiver architectures that employ analog-to-digital converters (ADC) with very low resolution, even as low as one-bit. Our focus is on ADCs since they are the most power hungry of an RF receiver?s components, and simplifications to the ADCs also allow for other components to be implemented with reduced complexity.

In order to counteract the significant non-linear distortion that low-resolution ADCs produce, intelligent signal processing algorithms must be employed for detection and decoding of the received signals. One particular approach we analyzed was the use of a special type of sampling architecture referred to as a "Spatial Sigma-Delta" (SSD) ADC. The advantage of this architecture is that it can be designed to reduce the ADC quantization error for specific directions from which the signals might arrive. We demonstrated that the SSD-ADC array could obtain performance that is very close to systems that employ much more expensive and higher power full-resolution ADCs. A second approach we studied was the use of machine learning tools to help with detection when low-resolution ADCs are employed. Due to their non-linearity, it is difficult to design optimal detectors for systems with such ADCs based on fundamental mathematical principles, since the statistics of the error cannot be exactly quantified. Instead, we proposed the use of machine learning approaches that used observations from the array to discover patterns in the data that could not be described mathematically, and then we used those patterns to design detection algorithms. This approach resulted in detection performance that is far superior to previous methods that had been proposed by researchers using algorithms based only on approximations to the true statistical models for the data.

In addition to the theoretical advances described above, we also designed and fabricated two CMOS integrated circuits that demonstrate new techniques for high-speed MIMO transceivers.  The first chip demonstrated a new technique for receiving and demodulating an RF signal that requires less complicated circuit blocks, thereby allowing for a smaller form factor and reduced power dissipation.  Another advantage of this new technique is that both the RF signal and the single-tone local oscillator that is used for the demodulation can combined and applied wirelessly to the chip.  The second chip demonstrated a four-channel MIMO transceiver, targeted for 5G cellular applications, that implements beamforming.  This chip also implemented a number of novel design techniques to achieve good performance, including a circuit that implements a precise (within 1 degree) phase shifting of the RF signal.

The project was used to support the studies of three graduate students who gained considerable expertise in the design of advanced wireless communications algorithms and circuit designs. All three of the students have graduated and are currently employed in the U.S. high-tech sector at Qualcomm, Apple, and Skyworks Solutions. One of these graduates is a female student, thus contributing to a more diverse workforce in this field.
